feed.title: Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System

entry.title: Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System
entry.summary: In a recent discussion, Antoine Riard addressed concerns regarding front-running resistance in a peer-to-peer marketplace. Front-running refers to the act of entering into a trade with advance knowledge of a block transaction that will impact the price of the underlying security. Riard proposed two security paradigms to mitigate this risk.The first paradigm involves duplicating the announcement of offers to multiple concurrent boards operated by independent identities. An infrastructure similar to a watchtower can monitor latency anomalies, and misbehaving boards can be disqualified from future announcements. The assumption is that at least one board is "honest" and there is a collective interest to avoid collusion.The second paradigm suggests running bulletin boards as a federation using consensus mechanisms like Honey Badger BFT. Offers become consensus items that must be announced to all federation members before publication. Earnings for federation members are tied to consensus publication, creating a level playing field. Riard acknowledged the flexibility of these paradigms in adjusting to different trade types and participant tolerance.Riard also discussed the CivKit framework for a flexible peer-to-peer marketplace. This framework combines Nostr architecture with Lightning onion routing to provide confidentiality. Market boards operate as Nostr relays with a Lightning gateway and can be run independently or as a federation. Trades are escrowed under Bitcoin Script contracts and rely on moderation and know your peer oracles for adjudication.To enable scoring of trades, counterparties, and service operators, Riard proposed using a Web-of-Stakes reputation framework. This framework assigns economic weight based on the Bitcoin UTXO set, serving as a trustless source of truth. Decentralized identifiers and Web-of-Trust techniques can also be incorporated.To incentivize service operators, Riard suggested using privacy-preserving credentials backed by Bitcoin payments. This aligns with the concept of Privacy Pass and encourages efficiency among market boards and oracles.Overall, Riard emphasized the importance of addressing front-running risks in a peer-to-peer marketplace and highlighted potential security measures and incentive frameworks to mitigate these concerns.In a recent post on the Lightning Dev mailing list, the authors of a paper announced their plans to release code and modules built on top of the Lightning Dev Kit and Nostr libraries. The paper delves into the system's architecture and expresses gratitude towards peer reviewers. The authors commit to adhering to open-source and decentralized standards established by Bitcoin Core and express their eagerness to collaborate with the community for standardization and interoperability.The authors welcome feedback from the community and provide links to additional resources such as the paper itself, the Lightning Dev Kit website, the W3C specification for Decentralized Identifiers (DIDs), and the Privacypass website. The post emphasizes the authors' intention to contribute to the Bitcoin ecosystem by releasing code that adheres to established standards and promotes collaboration within the community.
